Award.AwardTitle: The effects of charge transfer on aqueous and ionic systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Steven Rick of the University of New Orleans and Susan Rempe of Sandia National Laboratory are supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division to develop charge transfer (CT) models for ions and protein chains, building on previous work for water and to examine the effects of charge transfer on the properties of interfaces, water transport though nanochannels, ion solvation, and biological ion channels. Two often opposing principles, a need for efficiency and a need for accuracy, guide the development of interaction potentials for atomistic simulations. One strategy is to use quantum mechanical calculations or experimental results to determine the interaction types that are significant and then develop efficient methods for treating these interactions. Experimental and theoretical studies have demonstrated that charge transfer can play an important role in intermolecular interactions. Specifically, for two molecules in contact, the electron density is not equally shared between the two molecules. Thus, molecules can have small transient charges and ions can have non-integer charges. This amount of charge transfer may have important and largely unexamined effects on the thermodynamics and kinetics of condensed-phase systems. Studies of ions in non-aqueous systems, including ethylene carbonate and ionomers, are also planned. All these projects involve quantum mechanical calculations both to parameterize the CT models and to validate the results of the models.

This award supports theoretical and computational research aimed to develop and use simulation models with a new level of sophistication, without sacrificing computational efficiency. The understanding of materials at the molecular level is greatly enhanced by the use of computer simulations, which require a mathematical description of the interactions between particles. Charge transfer is a class of interactions commonly excluded in molecular simulations but which quantum theoretical calculations indicate is important. The quantum calculations reveal that charge can be spread out from a central molecule or ion to nearby particles. As an example, in water a chloride ion, with a formal charge of minus one, shares this excess charge with its neighbors and has a charge that is reduced by about 20%. The charge reduction of this and other ions is strongly environmentally sensitive, as its nearest neighbors change, impacting how ions interact and flow through various materials. This charge variation could have important consequences on the behavior of electrolytes as, for example, used in batteries, and in design of water desalination filters. This work would develop and use charge transfer models for the study of the structure and dynamics of ions and water in a variety of materials, including biological ion channels, water purification membranes, and battery materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project outcomes for this project in the previous year were in three areas. These projects span a range of systems, as described in the proposal, all of which relate to the mobility of ions. Understanding ion mobility is important for many systems, including batteries, water purification devices, and cell function.

Our specific outcomes are as follows.

1. Aqueous ions. The diffusion rates for water molecules in salt solutions depend on the identity of the ions, as well as their concentration. Among the alkali metal ions, cesium and potasium increase and sodium strongly decreases the diffusion constant of water. The origin of the difference can be understood by examining the simulation results using different potential models. We found that the key feature that separates models which sucessfully reproduce the experimental trend is the residence time of the water molecules in the first solvation shell of the ions. Aqueous ions diffuse with a number of tightly bound water molecules. How tightly bound these molecules are depends on the identity of the ion, and the motion of water into and out of the viscinity of the ion is strongly coupled to the diffusion rates of the ions. Ions with more tightly bound water molecules diffuse slower. This work in is press in the Journal of Chemical Physics.

2. Ionic liquids. Room temperature ionic liquids (IL) have applications as electrolyte solutions in batteries and capacitors, lubricants, and solvents for synthesis and catalysis. The highly charged nature of the system, in which all particles are charged, makes the simulations of IL a challence. We have extended the earlier work on this proprosal in the development of charge transfer models to the study of IL. In this model, small amounts of electronic density are transferred between neighboring ions, in amounts that capture the results of  quantum calculations. We used this model to understand how charge transfer effects influence the dynamics of IL. We have found that the ions have charges about 80% less than the formal charge and the exact value of the charge is strongly coupled to the motion of the ions. This work was presented recently at the American Chemical Society national meeting and is currently being prepared for publication.

3. Biological ion channels. Channelrhodopsins are light-activated ion channels that enable photomobility of microalgae that selectlvely transport cations through the cell membrane. When light-activated, they lose selectibity. Our computer simulations reveal that the mechanism for ion passage though the channel involves a gate, which can be opened by the loss of a single hydrogen bond. A paper on this work was published last year, in the Biophysical Journal, and a second paper is currently being prepared. This study involved a new experimental collaborator, which allowed for us to explore the predictions made by the simulations.
